text.p: Let [mathjaxinline]v_1 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]v_2 = \left[\begin{array}{c} 1 \\ -1 \\ 0 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] be vectors in [mathjaxinline]\mathbb R^3[/mathjaxinline].

Can you write the vector [mathjaxinline]x = \left[\begin{array}{c} -4 \\ -6 \\ -8 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline] as a linear combination [mathjaxinline]x = a_1 v_1 + a_2 v_2[/mathjaxinline]? If so, enter possible values for [mathjaxinline]a_1[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]a_2[/mathjaxinline]. If not, enter No in both boxes.

font.p:
We may notice that [mathjaxinline]x[/mathjaxinline] is a scalar multiple of [mathjaxinline]v_1[/mathjaxinline]:
[mathjaxinline]-2 \cdot \left[\begin{array}{c} 2 \\ 3 \\ 4 \end{array} \right] = \left[\begin{array}{c} -4 \\ -6 \\ -8 \end{array} \right][/mathjaxinline]
[mathjaxinline]-2 \cdot \, \, \, \, \, \, v_1 \, \, \, \, \, = \, \, \, \, \, \, \, \, \, \, x[/mathjaxinline]
It follows immediately that [mathjaxinline]a_1=-2[/mathjaxinline],[mathjaxinline]a_2= 0[/mathjaxinline] is a solution.
